title: I AM NOT THE LOCK PICKING LAWYER!!
tags: who is the lock picking lawyer?
description: There have been many rumors floating around that the Lock Picking Lawyer and I are one and the same. Today its time to put those rumors to rest. I am most definitely indeed not the Lock Picking Lawyer. Nor is the Lock Picking Lawyer myself. If we were the lock picking lawyers the the space time continuum would be totally out of wack. And we wouldnt want that.   Today we will be testing out a $300 facial recognition lock, which has a very catastrophic design flaw.   Watch all the EV Humvee build videos in order HERE:    Get my razor knife here!    Anker is named as the Official Charging Partner of JerryRigEverything:    *Follow me for updates!* Instagram:  Facebook:  Twitter:   LARGE tool kit:  Travel Tool Kit:  Mega Tool Kit:  Plastic Pry tools:  Metal phone opening tool:  Replacement phone parts:   The camera I used to film this video:  The Lens I used for this video:  Wide angle lens:  And this Metabones adapter:  This is the drone I use:   TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.O. Box on my 'About page':   JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: -[Zack] There have been a lot of rumors on the internet that I am secretly the Lock Picking Lawyer. -[The Lock Picking Lawyer's voice] This just isn't true. -[Zack] I do however like to review locks every now and then, and today we'll be reviewing a Visionis outdoor facial recognition lock. -[LPL] As the name suggests, this device can see your face, compare it with an internal database and then decide whether or not to allow access. -[Zack] Facial recognition might sound secure, but today I'll be showing you how a high tech lock like this can be defeated with an ultra low-tech bypass. Let's get started. [Intro] This lock costs about $300 on Amazon. It features a 4.3 inch touch screen, and dual 720p wide angle cameras that do the facial unlocking. Having two cameras supposedly helps defeat any facial spoofing. Also, the Visionis has enough internal storage to hold 1500 faces. -[LPL] Which when taken out of context sounds pretty creepy. But before we wire this up and install it, let's take it apart and see if there's anything that gives cause for concern. On the back there are 6 very common torque screws holding down the large metal panel. -[Zack] Once that panel is off we can see the large teal colored thermal foam cooling pad over the internal processor, along with the white rectangle up top. This helps transfer heat from the processor to the back metal panel. This facial recognition lock is ip65, which means it can be mounted outdoors. And judging by the rubber gasket around that inner edge, I have no reason to doubt that ingress protection. -[LPL] However, the protection I do doubt comes in the form of this small electromagnetic relay. It's just like the ones I use to control a variety of peripherals and systems in my ongoing EV Hummer project. Obviously, this one is a lot smaller, but also doesn't need to handle as much current. Presumably, this controls the flow of electricity to whatever device holds the door closed. If so, that could be a major security flaw. It may allow the lock to be tripped by holding a magnet to the outside of the unit. That's something we're going to test later. -[Zack] For now, let's put this back together, wire it up, and see how well it actually works. There is a wiring harness that plugs to the back of the unit before it's mounted on the wall. You can see there are a rainbow of wires, most of which I will not be using today. These allow the device to be set up in several different ways. -[LPL] It can be used as a standalone system, or as part of a network of access control devices. These different arrangements offer varying degrees of security. Since I do not have a network of access control devices, I'm going to set this up as a standalone system. -[Zack] That system is simulated with this demo board which has three main components, a 12 volt transformer which supplies power to the system. Then we have a button that would be securely placed inside the building to let people exit. Then we have the electronic strike itself which would lock the door when it's powered. If the power ever goes out, the door unlocks, which would insure that people won't ever be trapped inside. This is common and required by many fire codes. -[LPL] Now it's time to wire the harness to the demo board. I'll spare you the nitty gritty. The wires are now connected as shown in the instructions for a standalone system. Basically we have 12 volts powering the facial recognition unit, which then supplies power to the electronic strike, keeping it in the locked position. The exit button is also connected to the same base unit. The rest of the wires are not required in a standalone system, nor will they provide additional security unless we network this to a centralized access control system. That would be uncommon outside of large commercial facilities. -[Zack] Now, moment of truth, let's power this up. With the lock powered on, the strike is secured, unless we press the exit button from inside the building. [Beeping sounds] To set up the facial recognition, I'll activate the device with a pass code and set myself as the administrator. I'm pleased to see that this unit does not require an external app to operate. -[LPL] With my face now locally stored inside the base unit... -[Device voice] Thank you. -[LPL]...we can check the dual camera recognition. -[Device voice] Thank you. -[LPL] It does indeed work and surprisingly fast. When my face is not present, the strike remains in the locked position. Just for kicks and giggles, I'll try using a picture of my face to spoof the lock. But with dual cameras providing depth to the facial recognition software, there's no surprise that the lock remains secure. -[Zack] However, if you recall, I previously saw something that might be of concern inside the unit. There was a small relay, which is essentially a switch controlled by an electromagnet. And of course, if an internal magnet can actuate the switch, so too can a sufficiently powerful external magnet. Let's see if my concern was justified. -[LPL] You can see the unit is currently locked. However, if we bring the magnet close to that internal relay located near the bottom, even without my beautiful face in front of the cameras, it still magically opens. Not ideal for security. It's always interesting to see new lock technologies brought to the market. -[Device voice] Thank you. -[LPL] This one did seem to perform reasonably well when presented with my face. And equally important, it did not unlock when presented with a picture of my face. -[Zack] That said, a $300 lock being defeated in moments by a zero skill attack involving a $10 magnet is simply inexcusable. If Visionis would have used some form of solid state power switching, this would not have been a problem because there would be no moving parts to magnetically manipulate. Unfortunately, the company did not do that and this lock is not secure. -[Device voice] Thank you. -[LPL] If you are interested in learning more about lock defeat methods, you can always go subscribe to that Lock Picking Lawyer guy who is definitely not me. -[Zack] But he does seem like a pretty funny, and clever guy. -[LPL] Maybe even one of the funniest around. -[Zack] I don't think I would go quite that far. -[LPL] But then again, maybe I would. -[Zack] But what I can confirm without hesitation is that I'm definitely not the Lock Picking Lawyer. -[LPL] In any case, that's all I have for you today. -[Zack] Hit that subscribe button if you haven't already. -[LPL] If you do have any questions or comments about this, please put them below. -[Zack] And thanks a ton for watching. I'll see you around.
